chargeHist.descr: Ignition Interlock Device Tampering/Failure to Install/Violate Court Order

result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both Operating w/ PAC (4th) and OWI (4th). The defendant was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (4th) and the other charge, OWI (4th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Jonathan M. Plaza was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (4th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
9:17 a.m.   Defendant Jonathan M. Plaza in court with Attorney (Atty) William George Weiland. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Kelly A Cassidy appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard today are 22CF73 and 21CT157.

ADA Cassidy calls the case and states the appearances.

Plea Questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
21CT157:
Count 1 - Dismissed and Read In 
Count 2 - Dismissed
Count 3 - Guilty 
BAC .345

22CF73:
Count 1 - Dismissed and Read In 
Count 2 - Dismissed
Count 3 - Guilty 
BAC .175

Uncharged Read In of P22-00210 - Bail Jumping

Court questions defendant regarding plea questionnaire, waiver of constitutional rights and understandings.
Court advises defendant of elements the state must prove for the charge.
Court questions attorney for the defendant.
Court finds defendant's plea is freely, voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty of Count 3 in 21CT157:  OWI 3rd 346.63(1)(a) and guilty of Count 3 in 22CF73:  Operating with PAC (4th) 346.63(1)(b).
Clerk directed to enter judgment of conviction(s) this date.
Dismissed and Read In:  Count 1 of 21CT157 and Count 1 of 22CF73.
Dismssed:  Count 2 of 21CT157 and Count 2 of 22CF73.

ADA Cassidy makes sentencing arguments to the court. 
Atty Weiland makes sentencing arguments to the court. 
Sentencing is a joint recommendation.
Defendant makes a statement prior to sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
21CT157:
Count 3 -
Impose but STAY a 120 day jail sentence 
Eligible for huber for work, counseling and any other reason the sheriff will allow 
Eligible to serve up to one-half of the jail sentence on GPS home monitor, if he qualifies after an assessment

Placed in the Portage County Post Sentence Supervision Program for a period of 12 months 
*Comply with all conditions of the Post Sentence Supervision Program
*Pay fine and costs/applicable surcharges totalling $4,012
*60 days to pay or set up a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office 
*40 days of conditional jail 
*3 days of jail credit
*Report to jail today for start date 
*Eligible for huber for work, counseling and any other reason the sheriff will allow 
*Eligible to serve up to one-half of the jail sentence on GPS home monitor, if he qualifies after an assessment
*DL revocation for 31 months 
*IID for 31 months on any vehicle owned/operated by the defendant
*Complete an Alcohol/Drug Assessment or Department of Transportation Driver Safety Plan and comply with any recommendations.

22CF73:
Count 3 -
Impose but STAY an 8 month jail sentence - consecutive to 21CT157
Eligible for huber for work, counseling and any other reason the sheriff will allow 
Eligible to serve up to one-half of the jail sentence on GPS home monitor, if he qualifies after an assessment

Placed in the Portage County Post Sentence Supervision Program for a period of 12 months
*Comply with all conditions of the Post Sentence Supervision Program
*60 days of conditional jail - consecutive to the 40 days in 21CT157
*63 days of jail credit 
*Report to jail today for start date 
*Eligible for huber for work, counseling and any other reason the sheriff will allow 
*Eligible to serve up to one-half of the jail sentence on GPS home monitor, if he qualifies after an assessment
*Pay a fine of $2,000 plus costs and applicable surcharges
*60 days to pay or set up a payment plan with the Clerk of Courts Office 
*Permanent revocation of DL
*Complete an Alcohol/Drug Assessment or Department of Transportation Driver Safety Plan and comply with any recommendations.
*Provide DNA Sample

ADDRESS INFO for Jonathan M. Plaza
Current: 1600 Briggs St, c/o Salvation Army, Stevens Point, WI 54481 United States  (Effective: 09-02-2021)
Prior: 402 West St North, Stevens Point, WI 54481
Filed by Prosecutor.
Pre-trial conference on October 4, 2021 at 08:30 am.

*AMENDED 8/23/2021: 
Court modifies the bond to require the defendant to pay $250 up front and pay $100 each month after that with the final payment of $50 until $1,000 has been posted.
Conditions as originally stated will continue with the added conditions of:
No operation of a motor vehicle. 
The defendant is to be home from 9:30 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. except if he is working, then he can be at work or going directly to or from work. 

Conditions previously ordered:
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within the scope of your employment.
Comply with all other terms he is under of all his bonds.
Participate in the Portage County Pre-Trial Supervision Program and comply with the requirements for reporting, assessment, and programming.

10:11 AM Attorney (Atty) William George Weiland in court.  Defendant Jonathan M. Plaza appeared by video from the Waupaca County jail. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Kelly A Cassidy appeared for State of Wisconsin.

Atty Weiland indicates the defendant usually likes to appear in person and asks the court to confirm he would like to appear by video today. 
Court questions defendant and informs of the right to be present in the courtroom.
Defendant requests to appear telephonically for today's appearance and confirms that he/she can hear. 
Defendant indicates he/she understands the right to be present in the courtroom and has discussed with his/her attorney.
BY THE COURT: Court finds the defendant is knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily consenting to use of telephonic conferencing.

Atty Weiland makes bond arguments and requests a $250 cash bond. 
Atty Cassidy objects to any reductions in his bond and makes arguments to the court. 
Court questions Atty Cassidy. 
Atty Cassidy responds.  
Court refers to the counting statute, and this being a 4th offense should be a felony matter. 
Atty Weiland does not comment and understands what the court is saying. 
Court questions if the defendant was working before these offenses. 
Atty Weiland questions the defendant. 
Defendant states he was, he has a place to stay and two possible places for employment.   He will either be employed by Superior Health Linens in Plover and if that position is not available, he would be working at Rocky Rococco's.   He would be staying with the mens pastor at his church.  He can get a ride from anyone from his church or pay.  He can come up with $250. 

BY THE COURT: 
Defendant is facing a 4th offense OWI after having been charged with a 3rd offense only a few days prior. 
Court finds the bond that was previously posted was fair, but he has not been able to post that. 
Court modifies the bond to require the defendant to pay $250 up front and pay $100 each month after that with the final payment of $50 until $1,000 has been posted.
Conditions as originally stated will continue with the added condition of no operation of a motor vehicle. 

Court questions the defendant as to what hours he would be working. 
Defendant states he would be late shift at Superior or any hours he can work at Rocky's. 

BY THE COURT: 
The defendant is to be home by 7 p.m. except if he is working, then he can be at work or going directly to or from work. 

Defendant states he understands those conditions and asks if church would be allowed after 7 p.m. 
Court questions the defendant. 
Defendant states there are night services and a mens group. 

BY THE COURT: 
Curfew will now be 9:30 p.m. - 7:00 a.m. aside from work. 

Atty Weiland addresses the defendant to provide him and the court with any updated addresses and phone numbers so he can stay in contact.  

Court questions if the pre-trial conference has been done. 
Atty Weiland makes statements, they have but he needs to be able to speak to his client.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for October 4, 2021 at 08:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on August 23, 2021 at 10:00 am.

09:04 AM Defendant Jonathan M. Plaza in court with Attorney (Atty) William George Weiland. Defendant Jonathan M. Plaza in custody. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Jedidiah J Dodge appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Court calls case.
Court states appearances.

Attorney/Defendant received a copy of the criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of the charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of the complaint.

NOT GUILTY plea(s) entered.

BY THE COURT:  Bond continued.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for August 23, 2021 at 10:00 am.
